channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Dying Infants and No Medicine: Inside Venezuela’s Failing Hospitals
item.media:description: Yulitza Roa, 15, who has a brain tumor, is awaiting surgery that has been delayed because Luis Razetti Hospital does not have the needed scanning equipment.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Supplies are lacking, electricity goes out, equipment is broken and patients lie in pools of blood as the country’s economic crisis has exploded into a public health emergency.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: English Soccer Match Canceled Over Suspicious Package
item.media:description: The stands at Manchester United’s Old Trafford stadium were evacuated because of a suspicious package Sunday about 20 minutes before a game against Bournemouth was set to begin.
item.description: The game between Manchester United and Bournemouth on the final weekend of the Premier League season was abandoned after a package was found in the stadium.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Spanish Activists Push for Laws to Protect Whistle-Blowers
item.media:description: Ana Garrido said exposing corruption in her town had led to death threats.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: Spain is among just a few European nations with no legislation to protect anticorruption activists. Some say the system does the opposite.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: 50 Years After the Cultural Revolution, a Son Awaits Answers on His Father’s Death
item.media:description: Chen Shuxiang with images of his grandfather and a certificate showing that he had worked at a university. Mr. Chen treasures the images because he has none of his father, who was killed in the Cultural Revolution.
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.description: Chen Shuxiang’s father was killed by Red Guards in the first spasms of Mao’s Cultural Revolution. He has never learned why his father was singled out or what happened to his body.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Solar Project Pairs Muslims and Jews to Aid West Bank Farmers
item.media:description: A Palestinian worker in a date grove that is watered by a pump, powered by solar panels, in the West Bank town of Auja. The solar project was financed by Build Israel Palestine, a group involving both Muslims and Jews in the United States.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: Experts say the $100,000 environmental venture is the first substantial one in the West Bank to be financed by a group involving Muslims and Jews in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ and RAMI NAZZAL

item.title: Egypt Sentences 152 to Prison for Protest Over Transfer of Islands
item.description: A lawyer said some defendants had been randomly picked up off the street, as President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi continued a crackdown on dissent.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: South America’s Powerful Women Are Embattled. Is Gender a Factor?
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil is facing an impeachment trial.
item.description: Analysts say the collective decline of several current and former female leaders in South America points to a persistence of macho attitudes in the region.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Nicolás Maduro Tightens Hold on Venezuela as U.S. Fears Further Tumult
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela during a meeting with ministers in Caracas on Friday.
item.media:credit: Marcelo Garcia/Miraflores Press Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The country’s president threatened to seize idle factories amid economic chaos, and American officials warned that even his allies were turning against him.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY and MARK LANDLER

item.title: 2 Journalists in India Are Fatally Shot
item.description: The killings, in separate attacks over two days, raised questions about the safety of members of the news media.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: The Vaquita, the World’s Smallest Porpoise, Slips Closer to Extinction
item.media:description: The Mexican government has deployed fast boats, planes, helicopters and even drones to patrol for illegal fishermen.
item.description: Scientists say only about 60 are left in the Gulf of California, threatened by nets that fishermen illegally use to catch totoaba, a source of a Chinese delicacy.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Taliban Cut Off Afghan Highway Linking Kabul to Northern Gateways
item.media:description: President Ashraf Ghani has hailed the $3 billion Ring Road as a way to make Afghanistan the “hub” of Central Asia.
item.description: The $3 billion highway network has fallen into disrepair and come under insurgent control.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.category: Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction

item.title: Sinosphere: Explaining China’s Cultural Revolution
item.media:description: Premier Zhou Enlai, left, and the defense minister, Lin Biao, right, with Chairman Mao Zedong, waving copies of the “Little Red Book” of Mao’s sayings as they reviewed troops in Beijing in October 1967.
item.description: Fifty years after Mao Zedong unleashed a decade-long political upheaval intended to transform China, here is an overview of the key events, people and issues.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: For Obama, an Unexpected Legacy of Two Full Terms at War
item.media:description: President Obama accepting the Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo in 2009. Since then, he has tried to fulfill the promises he made as an antiwar candidate.
item.description: The president has approached conflict, and dealings with terror groups, as a chronic but manageable security challenge rather than an all-consuming national campaign.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Q. and A.: U.S. Combat Missions May End, but Fighting Goes On
item.description: President Obama inherited two wars from his predecessor, and has struggled to wind them down. American troops are still in both Iraq and Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Beer Purity Law, a German Tradition (and Marketing Tool), Turns 500
item.media:description: Greg Koch, 52, plans to distribute his Stone Brewing craft beers brewed in Berlin around Europe. But the beer purity law, or Reinheitsgebot, means that he will not be calling them German beers.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: Germans still revere their 500-year-old beer purity law, and insist it is the way to make beer, even though it is flexible when Germans want it to be.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Hezbollah Says Military Leader Died in Artillery Attack
item.description: A declaration regarding the killing of Mustafa Amine Badreddine raised more questions than it answered, including what the death says about Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Brazil’s Graft-Prone Congress: A Circus That Even Has a Clown
item.media:description: Brazil’s Senate voted Thursday to suspend President Dilma Rousseff and begin an impeachment trial against her.
item.description: The legislature contains a dizzying cast of characters, and, by one count, more than half of its 594 members face legal challenges.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Buddhist Monk Is Slaughtered at Temple in Bangladesh
item.description: A 75-year-old Buddhist monk was found hacked to death in his temple on Saturday, in a killing that bore similarities to attacks claimed by Islamist extremists.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: What in the World: Japan Has a Kit Kat for Every Taste, and Then Some
item.media:credit: Illustration by Craig Allen; Photos by Nestlé Japan
item.description: There are nearly 300 varieties of Kit Kat in Japan, where the candy is so popular that it is sold at high-end department stores, Kit Kat-only shops and even post offices.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: What in the World: The Wrong Day to Be a Cat in Belgium
item.media:credit: Illustration by Cari Vander Yacht; Photo by Inna Astakhova / shutterstock.com
item.description: The people of Ypres, Belgium, once dealt with feral cats by throwing them off a bell tower. Today, they host a cat-themed celebration instead.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK J. LYONS

item.title: What in the World: Look Out, Celebrity Chefs. Here Comes Kim Jong-un.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Antonio de Luca; Photo by KCNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Entities linked to North Korea run an expanding empire of restaurants abroad, pumping badly needed profits back to the North.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK J. LYONS

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Why Putin Tolerates Corruption
item.description: The West thinks it is the Russian president’s Achilles’ heel. It’s more like his shield.
item.dc:creator: IVAN KRASTEV

item.title: Opinion: Life as a North Korean Refugee
item.description: China should reverse its policy of hunting down defectors and returning them to its brutal neighbor.
item.dc:creator: HYEONSEO LEE

item.title: Editorial: Too Soon to Lift the Arms Ban on Vietnam
item.media:description: A parade in Ho Chi Minh City last year celebrating the 40th anniversary of the end of the Vietnam War.
item.description: President Obama should not feel obliged to give Vietnam’s authoritarian government what it wants.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: On the Ground in Aleppo: Bloodshed, Misery and Hope
item.media:description: A civilian evacuated a baby on Friday from a site that had been hit by airstrikes in a rebel-controlled area of Aleppo, Syria. Inhabitants of the city carry on with work and school despite fighting that has killed more than 200 civilians in the past week.
item.description: The New York Times’s Cairo bureau chief reported from Aleppo, Syria, where inhabitants try to carry on despite a civil war’s inescapable reality.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
